Day 5:
DAY 5 - YOUR IDEAL HOME

1. what changes would i make in communal spaces (kitchen, parking area, balcony):

KITCHEN
a) have a window. 
reasoning: the kitchen has zero windows and needs constant artificial lighting, which is a big put-off for us. Natural light is so important for wellbeing and it'd make staying in the kitchen much more pleasant. Plus, it'd increase the chances of my flatmates and I wanting to use it (the kitchen) as a shared/communal space where we hang out/ eat together. Also - I often want to eat in the kitchen, because I'm a big fan of separating the place I sleep from the place I eat, but because of the lack of light, it happens with some frequency that I end up going to the bedroom simply because there's natural light + a view in there.

b) have a kitchen table that accommodates all of us
reasoning: I think having a table in which we could all have a meal together would be so healthy for all of us. As I said, I'm a big fan of separating the bedroom space from the eating space, and often, when I'm by myself or with another flatmate, we eat in the kitchen - but if the 3 of us decided to do that, there'd simply be no space. Having a table that is appropriate for the amount of people that live in the flat would be cool. But it's not a big deal. 

PARKING AREA

one super cool thing we have suggested to the building management recently is to turn the car park plant boxes (which don't really have any plants, just dirt) into a residents' communal vegetables and flowers garden :) . Talking to people living in the building, we also realised it's quite cool to leave some stools and chairs downstairs to sit and chat.

BALCONY 

I think there's absolutely nothing I'd change about the balcony. I love it and it works so well as a communal space :)


obs: none of this would "significantly enhance my quality of life". I'm pretty good already.

However, here are a few points that would probably make me love my place even more
a) having access to a garden - to host parties, to hang out with friends, to plant food, to sunbathe, to write, to stretch in the morning.
b) having a "work area" separate from where my bed stays, so I could work and study in a space that's different from where I rest. and withdraw.


Long term housing plans

1. do I plan to live in my current place long-term?
for at least the next 2 years, yes. 

What factors influence my decision?
Convenience - which includes location, price, the tranquility of the sharing and chillness of the coexisting with my flatmates

2. Describe my ideal home in detail
see, this is not something that I think about at all. I'm quite satisfied, and "having an ideal home" is not my priority. 

However, If you asked me what an environment I'd like to live in would look like, I'd say communal living is definitely what I aim for. I think this ideal of living in a private space that is to be shared only what is considered a "romantic partnership" or blood-related-family doesn't help humans create community practices, collaborative problem-solving and collective development/ resilience. I want to have the privilege of sharing a living space with a community that shares the same quest for managing to cooperate, share responsibilities, income, and love, and develop a deep - and never-ending - research on mutual respect. To challenge traditional societal norms around individualism and ownership, promoting a model based on cooperation and mutual support - that'd be my dream / ideal. PLus, I really couldn't picture myself living all by myself or with a +1. That'd be so weird hahahha :)

Day 3:
Fortunately I’ve never been brought to tears by my accommodation. 
Coming back at the end of a day and chatting away to Clarissa.
It was the most cost effective option for student accommodation available near my uni.

I definitely want to stay around east London, and ideally have a tube stop within 15 mins walk. A place for my bike is also quite important.

Day 1:
I’m a filmmaker
4.⁠ ⁠⁠I live in London because it’s where me and my partner work, primarily

I live in a borough of West London. It’s me and my partner living together, just the two of us. It’s a one bed, one living room flat, so not massive. It’s about £980 a month, which we split. The living room is our only communal space as we are on the second floor of a multi-flat house. 
This is my side of the bed - it’s the room I sleep in but I share the room so this is really the only part that is “my room”. Non-direct light is important to me because overhead lighting stresses me out. We both use these little stools as night stands. We’re yet to put any art on the walls as I only moved in a few months ago, so that’s something I would change. We didn’t get our bed from ikea and it’s probably my favourite part of the room. 
This is our shared living room. I like the bookshelves and how the light comes in in the evening in the summer. My partner is artistic, and we paint without covering the cheap table underneath it, so it’s covered in splotches and scuffs. If I could change one thing in the room, I’d probably take out that stupid light in the top left corner which is both hard to dress in a lampshade because of where it is, but also why did they put it there in the first place? Having said that, it’s the light I use most in there because it’s cozy in the evenings.
Day 2:
The flat is too small overall but fine for now. I need a dedicated working space. We don’t have a tv because the space (“LR”) doesn’t work with one, which is fine for now but will change when we inevitably move. My childhood home was much bigger and we had a garden. I do like how it is all one floor. I do the washing up because I am better at it, as well as the hoovering. My partner does the surfaces as she has more patience for it. We both do the laundry. The clothes horse cannot be left up. These are rules because they keep the bits we care about most in terms of cleanliness done.
My piano sets me free. It is the easiest way to lose yourself. 
Camera corner, though not impressive to most, reminds me of what I do for a living.
Day 3:
I am feeling well

1. I actually so rarely cry that I’m yet to have cried here.
2. ⁠Me and my partner began a rare tradition of making “beige tapas” for dinner which involves getting around 5 ready meals from tesco and making them all at once. We really laughed the first time.
3. ⁠My partner rented first and I visited for a while before finally moving here last year.
4. ⁠I’m very intolerant of bugs. Recently, despite being on the second floor, we had an ant infestation. I’m really bad at dealing with them, because they’re a persistent pest. Knowing they’re in the house, I found it difficult to sleep. I haven’t seen them for a few days now but every now and then I’ll see just one - which tells me they’ve not truly gone.
This jug is special because I stole it from a project thinking it would be of my partner’s tastes and it was - one of the first times I had gotten something like that, and we bring it out as our dedicated water jug. 
I stuck this theme park map on the wall in our bathroom as a joke and we are both too stubborn to take it down. We should remove it because it’s not exactly wall art. But for now it remains a playful reminder of our dynamic.
Day 4:
I was on work calls all day and then in the evening I made dinner for me and my partner - and then we sat down to watch the new series of bridgerton. 

1. I spend at least 6 hours a day with my main housemate, who is my partner - she works away from home and is back in the evenings. At the weekends I’m practically with her the entire time.
2. ⁠We like to watch shows together. My health’s not been brilliant so we’ve not been going out as much as we used to.
3. ⁠Love the atmosphere of the house. We get along very well and communicate if there are any problems with the way we’re living together.

Our record collection made up of lots of oldies is something we are proud of and use interchangeably. Living room is geared towards socialising instead of a monolithic tv and this represents that. It’s a calm space. Music brings us all together. 
We keep to our own spaces for clothing. I don’t like my clothes getting mixed up with anyone else’s and prefer to be responsible only for my own clothes when it comes to washing. It’s easier to keep track of it and do it when required. I am logical on these specific things as clothes - and how and when we use them - are my own business. Having said what I said about laundry, the electric drying rack is something we all share as it means communal spaces are kept clear of laundry for more time. As the living room is supposed to be a communal space, this is vital
Day 5:
I’m feeling a bit better. Antibiotics are kicking in.

1. I would add a dishwasher if I could. So much time is spent washing dishes and the kitchen is the main focal point for cleaning. I took having a dishwasher at my parents’ house for granted and now I miss it. As dishwashers save energy and clean better than either of us can, it would be great for those reasons too. In last place, we would get a television. Too much time spent watching things on laptops and not looking straight ahead. But the space is too small for one right now and it’s not the right time.
2. ⁠It’s close to it. It doesn’t feel like a student house, which is very important to me. The main thing it lacks is space. I need an office. I would prefer we have two bathrooms because of my medical conditions. But for now, it’s nice.
3. ⁠We’re going to live here until the lease is up and then look at buying a house. They keep raising the prices for rent and it’s not really tied to anything sensical. I want to exit that system.
4. ⁠I want to be within reasonable walking distance to the closest tube/train station. Good public transport links mean everything to me. I want two bathrooms, two living rooms, and an office for my work, and as a place I can game. I would like a garden to plant wild flowers in and to do quick and easy laundry in the summer. And that’s probably in order of importance.
5. ⁠Because of house prices we’re looking to move as soon as possible. We’re wasting time renting. So, in 2025, we’ve got to get onto the housing ladder or risk falling behind. My work is lumpy - that is, unpredictable, but occasionally well paid - and if 2024 is a good year on that front then we’ll be able to get a house quite easily.

The record player as a centrepiece represents the sort of shared living space that me and my partner want. I miss having a television but it would be better suited to a different space, for a different purpose like that. This way, the living space feels more like a place geared for cozy interactions. 
If we had more lamps, we could make the space even more cozy. We lack surfaces to put them on so far, so that’s why we haven’t done that yet. But the few lamps we do have certainly make it a better living space

There are no house rules and no cleaning rota. There are no social spaces (no highlights), we never interact with flatmates. 
For photos that represent me, the one of in progress cooking from yesterday is very representative. 
Computer -something I spend too much time on, for work and play. Book collection - all I see are gaps, but next to one another (book and computer) are routes to my salvation and my doom, respectively. 
I would rather the computer didn't exist or at least wasn't such a s necessity, but it is a tempting portal out of my room and out of London more generally
Day 3:
A time when living in shared housing brought you to tears


I haven't thankfully been brought to tears in shared housing, but a flatmate of mine did not fare so well. Him (X) and I both lived with someone (Y) who I thought was cruel and manipulative, where he would spread false rumours. X would break down at odd times throughout the day, and although it was an odd hour he would cry so loudly you could hear it from every room.
After a while, instead of consoling him people would complain about the noise. 


A moment feeling happy

In this same house (of 7) as the first anecdote, I would love it when another flatmate (C) would invite people around. He was gregarious and new people from all different walks of life. He what I saw as a very European attitude to treating his guests - we would all drink, but sensibly, and we would always make food. Other people hated how there was no prior communication and people would just turn up. Having a big kitchen, living room, and garden was essential to this. I still had the sanctuary of my room to go to if I felt tired. The kitchen was so big I could do my cooking alongside theirs.

How did you come across your shared housing situation. 

I live in the same block of flats as I did last year, where there is an option to re-apply each year. You can state preferences of people you would like to be housed with, but the situation is that we have thousands of people applying to hundreds of rooms managed by one landlord, AA4S. It's like living in private university halls, but instead of corridors you are housed in flats of 4 to 6. I applied with my girlfriend and left it up to chance who the other two flatmates would be. 


An item that holds significant memories for you

This beautiful cajon was bought between our housemates in my first year of university towards the end of when we lived together. At the end our all-too-frequent COVID house parties, a group of us would generally end up drumming on whatever we could find - actual instruments, but also chairs, colanders, cooking chopsticks etc. It was magical. Eventually we got a bit more professional and bought some bongos, and cajons made of cardboard. Just before we left we invested in this more professional cajon, but as you can see from the label it has barely got any use in any of the houses I’ve been in since. It hasn’t been the right time, place, or group of people. An item that brings up memories to cherish.
Day 5:
The most significant change I could see is simply the additional of some sofas in our kitchen (with enough space left to still move around). In another flat in my block they have taken some sofas off the street and it has completely changed the dynamic of the space. Something comfortable to sit down in or sleep on makes such a difference. The space is so much more inviting. I wish the kitchen was ever so slightly bigger so that we could squeeze one in, and that the doorframes and corridors were a little wider so we could get the thing in and through the doors.

The second thing I would do is make communal spaces greener. The only communal spaces in my housing block are grey and covered in concrete. I can’t stress how lovely a garden is as something soft and earthy to lie down on, even if it’s just grass. This is a big hypothetical change, and I think is slightly less significant as I can’t imagine using it as much as a sofa. 

The third would be some less harsh lighting for the kitchen, so it looks less sterile. Tacky as it might be, putting up some Chinese lanterns would be great. I love the idea of adding both something to soften the mood, and something that looks like people have tried to claim the space and put some culture in to it. A flat I visit from time to time has Chinese new year stickers up everywhere and it always lifts my mood to see them. They’ve stuck good luck signs on their doors. It’s added such a sense of camaraderie, like they’re all creating the space together.



2. my current home is far from ideal. My bedroom is a nice sanctuary, but this year I haven’t done much to claim it as mine. The kitchen is like no-mans land, full of cooking stuff but nobody has left their mark there beyond cooking appliances left out. I want people to fill the space with their personalities. 


Long term plans

1.	My contract for this place ends in a few weeks. I’m glad about that, as I’d like to move on and try again someplace else, with more people I would rather with live with (my girlfriend of course being the exception!). Given the right bunch (as I’ve had in the past), I would want to really push the boat out and co-create the space that we want to live in, but with our flatmates it feels like a Sisyphean effort. They just don’t budge. I’m sure with enough effort I could have done something, but have been preoccupied with university commitments this year. I am feeling enthusiastic about giving it a better go and making where I next with feel more like a temporary home.

2.	My ideal home is leafy, green, rural, and most importantly of all, has enough space to be absolutely full of books. It’s surrounded by trees and you would access it by car, bike, or whatever crazy individual transport the future will dream up. I want it to be a detached house, home to maybe big extended family with plenty of guest rooms for people to stay as long as they like. People drop in and out but there are very often people stopping by. I don’t mind if the place is an absolute mess as long as it’s not dirty. Being filled with trinkets and other bits will add character. A big kitchen where plenty of people can cook together is a must. Some kind of intermediate between house and the outdoors is strongly desired, like a conservatory, pavilion, or balcony. I imagine it to be the perfect place to raise ‘free range’ children. Like a hobbit hole that outgrew its hillock and kept rising. I would try my best to tend to a garden, but I can’t promise much. A more general point here is that this is maybe the property I’d want to raise my children in. In later life, say, I’d like to live on the fifth floor in some smoky flat somewhere like Ljubljana. One giant study. From here I can live out the dream life as the cantankerous old professorial type where young cocky fools can debate the old man. Of great concern is what kind of place I’d like to live in before these examples. I have little clue and it causes me distress to a) not think I have much choice in the matter, and will follow whatever is affordable, and b) that I should probably be bracing myself for somewhere pretty grim. 


3.	I believe that such a house like this already exists. I have visited some like it and there are a few of them about, here in the UK or elsewhere. There might even be one in London, but I expect that such a place will be so coveted that everyone will know who lives there. I’d rather be somewhere more remote and hence more private, and more within budget. I could very well end up in one halfway across the world, though I would hate for it (and me) to be a little bastion of Englishness in a foreign land, like a governor and his residence. In truth community is not so important, friends can come visit! As to how I am going to get there, a good salary would certainly help.
I can't find a photo of an open fire but here's one I took of a wood burner while back home to illustrate this same point. 
Something that I think would be a wonderful addition to the communal space in my home but isn't considered feasible in this day and age. It's an aspiration for what communal space should be as it's not digital, and has people slow down and take it in. It's a great thing to look at when there's a pause in conversation. You can just take it in. You can boil tea on it or make beautiful patterns. It has this kind of primal significance and I think gets people to reflect on their (shared) humanity. Fires are brilliant but not going to happen in rented acommodation in London! I don't think you can burn wood in cities anymore. 
As in, this photo was sitting in my library when me and a friend of my were discussing a while ago this idea of what sort of things housing in London is missing.

Day 1:
1. I’m 20
2. I’m from a town in the countryside in Hertfordshire, close to London
3. I’m a student and I currently don’t work, but I take part time roles 
4. I live in London for university 
5. My accommodation is in Tottenham Hale, it’s managed by Unite Students. There are 700 odd students living here, but I share a flat with 6 other people. We have a communal kitchen between the 7 of us which has a breakfast bar style eating area with stools, and a couple of sofas at the back of the kitchen. In our flat there is no separate living room to the kitchen, it is all one space.  The accomodation has 2 courtyards, one is green with flower beds and benches, and the other is paved with stone slabs. There is also a common room where people can study or play pool/foosball.
Day 2:
1. See photo 
2. See photo (I can’t draw the other social spaces I mentioned such as the courtyard and common room, so just the kitchen)
3. I wish we had a separate living room because no one uses the sofas or sits in the kitchen to socialise. The kitchen feels like a dull and cold place, it’s not inviting. I think this is one of the reasons people in my flat don’t socialise together. However, I use the kitchen a lot because I enjoy cooking and even when I spend a couple of hours in the kitchen, I might not see any of my flatmates. My childhood home is completely different, they’re incomparable. We have lots of shared spaces in my childhood home, a proper living room and an open plan kitchen-dining room. We have doors that open out onto the garden from both the kitchen and the living room which allows the outside in. Our garden is a peaceful place with plenty of furniture to sit outside on nice days and enjoy the fresh air. That’s one of the things I miss the most about being in London.
4. I’m not sure how to answer this question, I don’t feel like we have any rules? None of us really know each other, we’ve never all been in the same room together and we don’t all communicate. We never set up rules and I don’t even feel like there’s many unwritten rules.
Day 3:
1. Missing home, feeling lonely here. Even though I have 6 flatmates it feels like I have none. I barely see them, I think I’ve been a whole week before without seeing anyone. That feels very lonely, human interaction is important for all of us. I think I had expectations before I moved in that as flatmates we would socialise or at least make an effort to. I realise we don’t have to be really close friends, but just people to talk to at the end of the day. 
2. A situation that made me laugh - I keep a tea towel on the handles of one of my cupboard doors. I always have. One day I noticed that it had moved from its normal home, it was screwed up in a soggy ball on one of the countertops. This was in Feb/March maybe? So I had been living here for quite some time, since September, and no one had ever used my tea towels before (thankfully). I took it as a one of, but then it kept happening again and again. The tea towels would turn up in random places around the kitchen, sometimes soggy, sometimes stained with oil. I couldn’t work out who was using it and what they were using it for, and it really frustrated me. I had to keep changing the tea towel as it was getting dirty more quickly. One day I walked into the kitchen and my flatmate Andrew was in there making some food, with my tea towel in his hand. Now you have to realise that the tea towel thief had been a mystery to me for a month or so, and in that moment, when I caught him red handed with the tea towel in hand, I couldn’t stop smiling. I found it so funny, so comical. After a month of frustration I had solved the mystery and he was completely unbothered. I didn’t say anything to him about it, I didn’t confront him. I just turned away and smiled to myself.
Day 4:
Hahah this is laughable to me, because realistically it’s zero. On the odd occasion I’ll end up in the kitchen at the same time as someone else, but that only ever happens with 2 people and they don’t talk to me. If I’m lucky we exchange a few words, so I wouldn’t call it ‘spending time with them’. 
2. Nope, none. We are all independent, completely disconnected. 
3. The communication is non-existent. There is a group chat that was made by the accommodation provider before we moved in and there was a little bit of chat on that previously. But there’s only ever a message if one of my housemates is locked out. We stay out of each others way, there are a couple of people I haven’t seen in months. Recently, the person I would say I was ‘closest’ too and had the most communication with, moved out without telling anyone. So that sums it up.
